hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?
You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Just needed some quiet before the crowds.
Spent my afternoon on old books—restoration, you could call it.
Things outside make hobbies… complicated lately.
Crowds quoting banned texts. Odd times.
Yes, before the rush and noise.
I restore banned political books for clarity, not nostalgia.
Recent protests echoed lines I just finished repairing.
Feels surreal, honestly. Paper matters again.
You never know who’s listening these days.
Slipped out before things got loud.
Collect and restore old political literature—paper originals, when I can find them.
Protests borrowed lines from a book I was working on today.
Feels like history’s leaking into the streets.
Strange when strangers chant your day’s hobby.
These times do odd things to old words.
Beat the rush. Needed space to focus earlier.
Collecting and restoring banned texts is my odd little vice.
The Mandate nearly crumbled in my hands today—right as I heard chants outside.
Quotes from that book echoed across the square.
I’ve restored dozens over the years, mostly for myself.
With the leaks, more people seem hungry for those words again.
Makes me wonder if secrets ever truly stay hidden.
Escaped the crowds, but my mind’s still buzzing.
I collect and restore banned political literature, a habit since university.
Some texts—like today’s—nearly vanished in the system purge a decade back.
I was restoring 'The People’s Mandate.' It’s not just ink. It’s subtext, meaning layers.
Protesters outside chanted lines I handled minutes before. Felt surreal.
Used to be scholarly—now, it’s border-line dangerous again.
The BCI failures meant some got freer passes at checkpoints than I did.
Hard to explain the thrill of holding words that terrify systems, even now.
hobby_answer: Still collecting, yes. Quietly.
Finding anything now draws more attention than usual.
After Rada’s broadcast, everyone’s on edge about old words resurfacing.
I keep my restoration work brief these days.
Best not to risk lingering on old ideas.
I pick up a page now and then. Cautious, of course.
Rada’s exposé means even restoring these relics feels different now.
Strange to see protestors quoting what I’ve tucked away.
You’d think banned texts would fade—but now, eyes are everywhere.
Sometimes I hide the good stuff in plain sight.
Used to be a risk. Now it’s a potential warning sign.
Still chasing lost pamphlets and speeches, always under the radar.
Irony is, after the Directorate secrets came out, the streets sound like my library.
Restoring a manifesto isn’t just historic anymore—it’s political again.
My new acquisitions drew suspicion last week—checkpoints changing, patterns off.
Even my BCI drop flagged a hobbyist move.
Feels like compliance never really meant safety; now it’s visible.
Guilty as charged. Just got my hands on a first edition—pre-ban seal, too.
Funny, after the secret room scandal, passages I’ve restored show up at protests.
Was patching up “Mandate” last weekend when chants echoed the same text.
Used to keep restoration private; now even paper dust feels risky.
BCI’s glitch dropped my score after a checkpoint found faded covers in my bag.
Feels surreal: once these words were evidence, now inspiration—or a new kind of target.
Hard to predict whether the next find earns curiosity or gets me flagged.
Guess I’ve never felt the system’s cracks so personally before.
Of course, still searching out banned literature. Some instincts don’t fade.
My shelves are a reflection of what people aren’t supposed to remember.
During the blackout, for a few hours, I restored a pamphlet at the window—felt almost safe.
After the exposé, protestors quoted lines I was literally repairing.
One activist left a copy by my door, unsigned but well-used.
Even old covers trigger BCI drops; last week, my “eccentric” tag nearly tipped me into flagged status.
Funny, I collect these because the words resonate—now the city’s chanting them aloud.
I used to think restoration was a private rebellion. Now, the boundary blurs.
There’s satisfaction and danger in it, especially as the system’s mask slips.
